items.name: Laylat al-Qadr Possibility (20)
items.quote: “The last ten nights begin—do not miss a single one.”
items.description: The search for Laylat al-Qadr starts. Begin strong.

todos.label: Start night prayers with sincerity
Begin focused Quran reading plan
Make dua for strength to continue
Set a quiet, worshipful atmosphere
Plan your remaining nights intentionally

facts: The last ten nights begin on the 20th night.
Some scholars believe Laylat al-Qadr *could* fall on any of the last ten nights, not just odd.
A strong start builds momentum for the rest of Ramadan.
Routine and sincerity matter more than overexertion on just one night.
This is a night to prepare your heart and calendar.

items.name: Laylat al-Qadr Possibility (21)
items.quote: “Seek Laylat al-Qadr in the last ten nights of Ramadan.”

todos.label: Pray extra night prayers (qiyam/taḥajjud)
Read or listen to Quran
Make heartfelt dua and ask for forgiveness
Give charity, even if small
Encourage family to join in worship

facts: Laylat al-Qadr is known as the Night of Power or Decree.
Its exact date is unknown, but it is sought in the odd nights of the last 10 of Ramadan.
Worship on this night is better than a thousand months.
The Quran was first revealed on Laylat al-Qadr.
Signs of Laylat al-Qadr include a peaceful night and a calm sunrise.

items.name: Laylat al-Qadr Possibility (22)
items.quote: “Do not assume Laylat al-Qadr is only in the odd nights.”
items.description: Stay consistent. This might be the night of immense reward.

todos.label: Attend prayers and engage in quiet reflection
Journal your reflections during this journey
Pray for the guidance of others
Study a short tafsir of Laylat al-Qadr
Forgive someone in your heart

facts: There are reports suggesting Laylat al-Qadr may fall on an even night.
Consistency across all nights reflects sincerity.
A quiet heart and focused worship are key.
This is a test of endurance and intention.
Seek Laylat al-Qadr even when it's not popular to do so.

items.name: Laylat al-Qadr Possibility (23)
items.quote: “Whoever stands in prayer on Laylat al-Qadr out of faith and hope, will have past sins forgiven.”

todos.label: Attend or host night prayers at home or mosque
Recite abundant dhikr (remembrance)
Read Surat al-Qadr and reflect on its meaning
Ask Allah for guidance, forgiveness, and Paradise
Share knowledge or a good reminder with others

facts: Many scholars recommend extra worship on every odd night in the last ten nights of Ramadan.
The Prophet Muhammad ﷺ encouraged seeking Laylat al-Qadr with dedication.
Many Muslims stay up the whole night in worship, dua, and reflection.
Charity is multiplied in reward during these nights.
Laylat al-Qadr is a time to ask Allah for anything good.

items.name: Laylat al-Qadr Possibility (24)
items.quote: “Even nights are not empty of blessings.”
items.description: Continue the momentum. Rewards may be written for you tonight.

todos.label: Recite Quran with understanding
Go outdoors and observe the night in silence
Pray deeply with long sujood
Give a small, secret act of kindness
Remind others to not skip even nights

facts: Every night of the last ten carries potential blessing.
Laylat al-Qadr is hidden to encourage ongoing devotion.
Rewards multiply even if it's not the exact night.
Many people mistakenly neglect even nights.
Quiet, sincere worship counts more than dramatic displays.

items.name: Laylat al-Qadr Possibility (25)
items.quote: “Seek it in the odd nights of the last ten nights of Ramadan.”

todos.label: Dedicate time for personal prayer and gratitude
Reflect on the mercy of Allah in the Quran
Spend time in calm, silent reflection
Break your fast with family and then worship together
Send a reminder to friends to seek Laylat al-Qadr

facts: Some traditions suggest Laylat al-Qadr can fall on the 25th night.
It is encouraged to repeat the special dua: “Allahumma innaka Afuwwun tuhibbul afwa fa’fu anni.”
The rewards of Laylat al-Qadr include forgiveness and immense blessings.
Muslims intensify their worship and good deeds in these nights.
Giving charity and being kind to others is highly recommended.

items.name: Laylat al-Qadr Possibility (26)
items.quote: “One of these even nights could be the one.”
items.description: Refocus your energy. The finish line is near.

todos.label: Participate in full taraweeh if possible
Spend extra time in dhikr
Pray for barakah in the remaining Ramadan days
Share iftar or food with someone in need
Listen to a powerful reminder about Laylat al-Qadr

facts: The 26th night is often overlooked but still significant.
Laylat al-Qadr can fall on *any* night in the last ten.
Consistent effort is a sign of sincere iman (faith).
Reflect on what you’ve gained spiritually so far.
Prepare your heart for the final push.

items.name: Laylat al-Qadr Possibility (27)
items.quote: “It is widely believed that Laylat al-Qadr may fall on this night.”
items.description: Seek Laylat al-Qadr this night. There is more possibility it falls on this night as per hadiths etc.

todos.label: Join congregational prayers and taraweeh
Read more Quran than usual tonight
Pray for the entire ummah
Reflect on the significance of Laylat al-Qadr
Forgive others and seek forgiveness

facts: The 27th night is commonly regarded by many communities as Laylat al-Qadr.
However, the Prophet ﷺ did not specify the exact date.
This night sees increased attendance at mosques worldwide.
Many Muslims give special charity tonight.
It is a night of spiritual renewal and hope.

items.name: Laylat al-Qadr Possibility (28)
items.quote: “Finish strong. Any night may be *the* night.”
items.description: Nearly there. Don't drop your guard now.

todos.label: Pray qiyam with extra reflection
Revisit verses about mercy and forgiveness
Make personal duas for your future
Send reminders to others not to give up yet
Thank Allah for allowing you to reach this far

facts: The 28th night is the last even night of Ramadan.
Finishing Ramadan strong is more important than starting strong.
Every act of worship counts—even when tired.
This night may surprise you with peace and clarity.
Every minute of sincerity is a treasure.

items.name: Laylat al-Qadr Possibility (29)
items.quote: “Never stop seeking Laylat al-Qadr until Ramadan ends.”

todos.label: Make an effort to worship even as Ramadan ends
Thank Allah for the blessings of the month
Pray for peace for yourself and others
Sleep after Fajr with peace in your heart
Send encouragement and duas to friends

facts: The last odd night of Ramadan is another opportunity for Laylat al-Qadr.
Consistency in seeking the night is a sign of sincere faith.
Many scholars advise not to neglect the 29th night.
As Ramadan ends, continue making dua for acceptance.
The doors of mercy are open until the very end.

items.name: 2nd Dhul-Hijjah
items.quote: “Fasting in these days is greatly rewarded.”
items.description: Continue your devotion with increased focus.

todos.label: Fast today if able
Learn about Hajj rituals
Increase in dhikr: SubhanAllah, Alhamdulillah, Allahu Akbar
Give small charity
Remind a friend to join in these deeds

facts: The Prophet ﷺ used to fast the first 9 days of Dhul-Hijjah.
Good deeds are multiplied significantly during these days.
Simple acts like dhikr and dua are greatly rewarded.
The Day of Arafah is approaching — prepare spiritually.

items.name: 3rd Dhul-Hijjah
items.quote: “Every act of worship is magnified during these days.”
items.description: Use today to reflect and renew intentions.

todos.label: Continue Quran reading or listening
Pray for forgiveness and sincerity
Help someone in need
Study one name of Allah
Share a meaningful reminder online

facts: Reflection and humility are key during these days.
Giving charity is one of the most beloved acts.
The Prophet ﷺ emphasized dhikr throughout these ten days.
You can gain immense reward through small consistent actions.

items.name: 4th Dhul-Hijjah
items.quote: “Let your actions speak louder than your posts.”
items.description: Focus on quiet, consistent ibadah today.

todos.label: Recite 100x each: SubhanAllah, Alhamdulillah, Allahu Akbar
Make a dua list for the Day of Arafah
Read a passage about Hajj or Ibrahim (AS)
Reach out to someone you’ve wronged
Do something helpful at home quietly

facts: Consistency is more beloved than grand gestures.
Internal character growth is a form of ibadah.
Don't underestimate dhikr during mundane moments.
Preparing your heart for Arafah starts early.

items.name: 5th Dhul-Hijjah
items.quote: “The believer is always seeking to improve.”

todos.label: Reflect on a recent mistake and seek forgiveness
Pray Salat al-Duha
Make a specific dua for your future
Send a heartfelt message to a loved one
Read verses about accountability or tawbah

facts: Salat al-Duha is a sunnah prayer with great reward.
Tawbah (repentance) is a core practice of these days.
Small improvements in character are signs of faith.
Allah loves those who return to Him sincerely.

items.name: 6th Dhul-Hijjah
items.quote: “The best of you are those who benefit others.”
items.description: Serve others today for the sake of Allah.

todos.label: Give a thoughtful gift or donation
Call someone who’s alone or struggling
Prepare or deliver a meal to someone
Say something kind to someone unexpected
Make dua for someone who hurt you

facts: Acts of service carry enormous weight in Islam.
The Prophet ﷺ was known for serving his companions.
Charity during these days is multiplied.
Kindness, even in speech, is a form of sadaqah.

items.name: 7th Dhul-Hijjah
items.quote: “The reward is with Allah, not the people.”
items.description: Detach from the need for validation. Focus inward.

todos.label: Take a break from social media
Pray long sujood and just talk to Allah
Read about the farewell sermon of the Prophet ﷺ
Make dua without asking anything—just gratitude
Journal your feelings or growth this week

facts: Sincerity (ikhlas) is the soul of all worship.
Being unseen by the world can be a blessing.
The Prophet ﷺ gave his final advice to us during Hajj.
The seventh night prepares your heart for Arafah.

items.name: 8th Dhul-Hijjah (Yawm al-Tarwiyah)
items.description: Reflect on the journey of Hajj and prepare for Arafah.

todos.label: Watch or read about Hajj rituals
Pray for the safety and acceptance of all pilgrims
Recite takbeer after prayers
Reflect on the sacrifice of Prophet Ibrahim (AS)
Commit to one sacrifice in your life (habit or ego)

facts: Yawm al-Tarwiyah is when pilgrims begin their Hajj.
It reminds us of spiritual journey and intention.
We are all on a path toward Allah—Hajj just makes it visible.
Sacrifice is the theme of these days.
